questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A service provider engineer is configuring the connection between CE1 and CE2. AS 200 of the service provider and AS 100 of enterprise ABC should connect using BGP. The engineer already completed the configuration of VRF RT 100:10 of enterprise ABC. Which configuration must the engineer apply on PE1 to meet the requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
In the exhibit, the bgp neighbor from PE1-CE1 is already configured. Hence, it doesn't require it again. However, there is no VRF configuration. Hence, it requires configuring the VRF.

vrf has to be IPv4 address family, not the VPNv4

comments.content:
The engineer already completed the configuration of VRF RT 100:10 of enterprise ABC


104 / 5.000
Resultados de tradução
Resultado da tradução
If this VRF is already configured, how are you applying a vrf with a different name to client ABC?

discussion.content:
In the exhibit, the bgp neighbor from PE1-CE1 is already configured. Hence, it doesn't require it again. However, there is no VRF configuration. Hence, it requires configuring the VRF.

vrf has to be IPv4 address family, not the VPNv4

Selected Answer: B
Either way I will go for B.
U do not need vpnv4 afi for neighborship
U need ipv4 afi for neighborship
Also need to define the RD for that specific route as it traverses the mpls core

comments.content:
Yeah I think B has the least wrong with it.
A and D seem to be configuring vpnv4 with the customer, which is wrong.
C looks to be configuring the ipv4 afi with the other PE, which is wrong.

But Karen is right VRF is missing from output on PE1 BGP neighborship to CE1
and loopback is misleading.. however the principles of MPLS should still be in place

discussion.content:
This question doesn't make any sense. PE1 and CE1 have the same loopback IP 10.10.10.1
If PE1 is configured with a neighbor statement to 10.10.10.1, it will not form a neighbor with CE1. Also, the neighbor config with CE1 needs to be under "router bgp 200 vrf vpnABC".

Good luck if you see this question on your exam.

comments.content: And nevertheless, Answer A is wrong because being in the vrf vpnABC address space, it should not use address-family vpnv4, (should be address-family ipv4 unicast).. I still support answer B because the config needs a vrf definition (and agree with Karen1337 that it should be called vpnABC). So many errors in these questions.

I do agree that the question is poorly designed. because the answer needs to specify vrf vpnABC. However, I don't think the duplicate 10.10.10.1 is a problem. CE1 address 10.10.10.1 is in the vrf vpnABC address space, which is allowed to overlap with the global address space. I hope I don't get this question on the exam. I agree that B has the least wrong with it, and the config needs a vrf Definition. Which Cisco platform requires that you specify an address family in the vrf? IOS doesnt. XR? XE? Answer B

questions.question_text: A network architect must implement CSC VPN services for a new backbone earner. Which two benefits does the architecture provide? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
Yup! B and E ==> for backbone

Selected Answer: BE
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/mp_ias_and_csc/configuration/xe-16-12/mp-ias-and-csc-xe-16-12-book/mpls-vpn-carrier-supporting-carrier-using-ldp-and-an-igp.html

Go to the section "Benefits to the Backbone Carrier"
The first two bullet points cover B and E

choices.B: It supports a scalable growth strategy that services multiple customers efficiently.
choices.A: It leverages IPsec to establish connections within the backbone, which eliminates the need for BGP to distribute routes.
choices.D: It eliminates the need to maintain a centralized network-maintenance and operations strategy.
choices.E: It maintains a single backbone, which simplifies the VPN implementation to customers.
choices.C: It relies on IP communications, which simplifies the network design.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Auth: AuthNoPriv
Priv: AuthPriv 
NoAuth: NoAuthNoPriv
so option A is correct

snmp-server group mygroup v3 auth
snmp-server user AuthNocUser nmsgroup v3 auth md5 <authentication-password> priv des <encryption-password>

Answer: A
snmp-server user AuthNocUser nmsgroup v3 auth md5 <authentication-password> priv des <encryption-password>

Selected Answer: A
Question asks for Authentication and Encryption... therefore only option A provides this for us. It didn't asks us what encryption to specifically use, so we can just use anyone we want.

Auth: AuthNoPriv
Priv: AuthPriv
NoAuth: NoAuthNoPriv
so option A is correct

Selected Answer: B
Process of elimination only b makes sense.
May be some output in answers were missing for encryption protcol (des/3des/aes)

comments.content: Option B does not have encription option as option A
I think option A is the answer. Option B does not have encription.

discussion.content: I don't understand how B is the answer. It specifically asks for encryption, and B doesn't include any encryption. I used this config in a lab to confirm the SNMP packets aren't encrypted if you use SNMPv3 and only do Auth.

questions.question_text:
The NOC engineer in a service provider network must configure an SNMP community on switch SW with these security attributes:

• Event messages must be authenticated with the MD5 algorithm and encrypted.
• The remote user name for the SNMP server at 172.16.10.1 is AuthNocUser.

Which configuration must the engineer apply to the switch?
Why is the keyword none needed when implementing management plane security using TACACS+?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The none keyword ensures that there is a fallback mechanism when TACACS+ is unavailable, preventing management lockouts and maintaining access to the device for administrative purposes.

Selected Answer: D
allows access only when the previous methods are not available. Not to be confused with failed auth.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
Keyword Definition
local Local username authentication
local-case Case-sensitive local authentication
enable Enable password or enable secret
none No authentication

comments.content:
Agree. D is correct. See table 4 in the following document
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/sec_usr_aaa/configuration/xe-3s/sec-usr-aaa-xe-3s-book/sec-cfg-authentifcn.html 
none | Uses no authentication

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
It allows the local database to authenticate users when the TACACS+ is unreachable. New users created after the server went down and users not in the local database will not be able to authenticate.

choices.A: It allows the local database to authenticate when the TACACS+ server is unreachable
choices.C: It prevents all users from accessing router 1 unless the TACACS+ server is reachable
choices.B: It allows the router to query a RADIUS server when the TACACS+ server is unreachable
choices.D: It allows authentication to succeed when the TACACS+ server is unreachable

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. To protect in-band management access to CPE-R7, an engineer wants to allow only SSH management and provisioning traffic from management network 192.168.0.0/16. Which infrastructure ACL change must be applied to router PE-R9 to complete this task?

choices.B: ip access-list extended INFRA-ACL no 10 15 permit tcp 192.168.0.0 0.0.255.255 range 49152 65535 100.64.0.0 0.31.255.255 eq 22
choices.C: ip access-list extended INFRA-ACL 15 permit tcp 192.168.0.0 0.0.255.255 range 49152 65535 100.64.0.0 0.31.255.255 eq 22
choices.D: ip access-list extended INFRA-ACL no 10 15 permit tcp 192.168.0.0 0.0.255.255 eq 22 100.64.0.0 0.31.255.255 eq 22
choices.A: ip access-list extended INFRA-ACL 15 permit tcp 192.168.0.0 0.0.255.255 range 49152 65535 100.64.0.0 0.31.255.255 eq 443

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The 'no 10' is required to remove the acl line allowing telnet. It should have a line break at that point though which would make this question clearer.

answer C
Syntax if the command line in B is incorrect

Selected Answer: B
Only answer possible is B
You need to remove line 10 which allows the telnet, then allow ssh. 
NOTE: the SOURCE ports will be from the dynamic port range, not from port 22 but the DESTINATION port will be port 22.

Selected Answer: C
If we look at the question we notice that the Ip access-list ANFRA-ACL permit syntex does not have the "no" found in options B and D.

comments.content: That makes no sense, the answer is B. " allow only SSH management" so you must remove the telnet access line 10
B says to remove a acl rule with port 22 (22 = ssh). there is no such rule in the current config?

discussion.content: B is correct
